newsitem.title: USA: US W.Coast distillates rise on refinery rumors.
newsitem.headline: US W.Coast distillates rise on refinery rumors.

text.p: U.S. West Coast spot distillate prices rose Thursday on rumors that distillate supplies could shrink because of problems at one of Tosco's distillate-making units in Los Angeles, traders said.
"Tosco said it was a diesel unit that was affected," one trader said.
The company could not immediately be reached for comment.

However Tosco yesterday said it had begun to cut back intake of crude oil in its San Francisco refineries, but declined to say how much. It was unclear whether run cuts or mechanical problems affected Tosco's production.
Other refiners were rumored to be cutting use of crude, which has risen dramatically compared to products.
Exxon today said it had not cut runs at its Benecia, Calif., refinery near San Francisco.
Futures prices also rose, with heating oil for June delivery on the NYMEX up 0.25 cents a gallon Thursday to 57.80 cents, and unleaded gasoline up 0.40 cents.
++ DISTILLATES: June CARB diesel in L.A. rose two cents to 64.50/65.50 cents. Low sulphur diesel, or "EPA" grade also rose two cents to 59.50/60.50 cents.
++ GASOLINE: Traders pegged offers for June CARB unleaded gasoline at 64/65.75 cents a gallon in Los Angeles.
Conventional grade stood 60/61 cents a gallon.
